newsitem.title: SLOVENIA: Slovenia shares fall but seen rising in January.
newsitem.headline: Slovenia shares fall but seen rising in January.

text.p: Slovenian shares fell 2.46 percent in low turnover on Monday, the year's first trading day, as a result of a technical correction following book balancing rises at the end of last year.
"The fall was purely a technical correction after prices rose on book balancing at the end of the year," said Mateja Gubanec, a trader of bank A banka.
"I think growth can be expected in January due to positive expectations as prices usually grow at the beginning of the year," he added.
The 10-share SBI index fell 29.16 points to 1,156.
Overall, seven shares fell, five rose and 13 were untraded.
Turnover fell to 25.1 million tolars from 653.6 million on December 30 -- the last trading day of 1996.
"As the holidays have just ended, turnovers may remain low throughout the week," one broker said.
Drug company Lek's issue A had the highest turnover firming 0.51 percent to 19,600 tolars on volume of 624 shares for total turnover of 12.2 million tolars.
Warehousing company BTC was the leading decliner, closing 33.52 percent lower at 9,300 tolars on volume of 28 shares for total turnover of 0.3 million tolars.
Financial consultancy Primofin was the top gainer, rising 6.72 percent to 20,010 on volume of nine shares for total turnover of 0.2 million tolars.
